From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


2020 Australian film


I Met a GirlTheatrical release posterDirected byLuke EveWritten byGlen DolmanProduced byAdam DolmanStarring
Brenton Thwaites
Lily Sullivan
Joel Jackson
Zahra Newman
Anita Hegh
CinematographyPatrick O'SullivanEdited byMelanie AnnanMusic byMatteo ZingalesProductioncompanyMonsoon PicturesDistributed byGravitas Ventures (United States)Release date
11 September 2020 (2020-09-11)
CountryAustraliaLanguageEnglish
I Met a Girl is a 2020 Australian romantic drama film directed by Luke Eve and written by Glen Dolman. The film stars Brenton Thwaites, Lily Sullivan, Joel Jackson, Zahra Newman and Anita Hegh.[1]
It was released on 11 September 2020, by Gravitas Ventures in the United States.


Premise[edit]
A young man who suffers from schizophrenia embarks on a journey across Australia to find Lucy, the woman of his dreams, whom he met in Perth - or did he?

Cast[edit]
Brenton Thwaites as Devon
Lily Sullivan as Lucy
Joel Jackson as Nick
Zahra Newman as Olivia
Anita Hegh as Patricia
David Woods as Soul
Peter Rowsthorn as Mr. Rocket
Anni Finsterer as Miss Needle
Vivienne Garrett as Female Driver
Production[edit]
The film was director Luke Eve's first feature film. He researched the mental health issues it portrays thoroughly, and consulted the mental health organisation SANE about the script. He described the film as "not a hard hitting portrayal of mental illness. It's about somebody with schizophrenia, but wrapped up in a fantastical love story".[2]
After being filmed in Australia, the film's festival and theatre release schedule was interrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic.[2]

Release[edit]
I Met a Girl had its world premiere at the 25th Busan International Film Festival.[3] It was released  in the United States and Canada by Gravitas Ventures on 11 September 2020 as a premium video on demand release,[4][5] followed by release on streaming platforms Hulu and Amazon.[2]
It was subsequently released in cinemas in Germany and South Korea,[2] and on Netflix in Australia and New Zealand on 2 April 2021.[3]

Reception[edit]
Roger Moore of Movie Nation gave the film a 2/4 and said "The best one can say for the script is that it gives the charming stars a nice moment or two, and that it generally doesn't fall for the "Love can cure what ails you" mental health rom-com trap."[6] John Nolan of Punch Drunk Critics scored the film 2.5/5 stars, stating "While new ground isn't exactly broken I Met A Girl does an admirable job delivering exactly what fans of this emerging sub-genre are looking for while being respectful of the struggles faced by it's [sic] protagonist."[7]
ScreenHub Australia gave the film 3.5/5 stars.[8] Andrew F. Peirce of The Curb praised Thwaites' performance, and called the film "a proudly grounded, human experience... that lingers longer in your mind than the possible light rom-com filmic creation that the base synopsis would suggest".[9]

References[edit]

^ "Brenton Thwaites Hopes She is Real in Romance 'I Met a Girl' Trailer". First Showing. September 2020. Retrieved 14 October 2020.

^ a b c d Keast, Jackie (6 April 2021). "Luke Eve's 'I Met A Girl' finds a happy ending". IF Magazine. Retrieved 30 May 2022.

^ a b "Airdate: I Met A Girl". TV Tonight. 24 March 2021. Retrieved 30 May 2022.

^ "New Australian film feature film I Met a Girl to launch in North America". FilmInk. 4 September 2020. Retrieved 30 May 2022.

^ "US digital release for Luke Eve's 'I Met a Girl'". IF Magazine. 4 September 2020. Retrieved 14 October 2020.

^ Rogerinorlando (10 September 2020). "Movie Review: Schizophrenic and "I Met a Girl"". Movie Nation. Retrieved 14 October 2020.

^ Nolan, John (11 September 2020). "Review: 'I Met A Girl'". Punch Drunk Critics. Retrieved 14 October 2020.

^ "Film Review: I Met a Girl handles Schizophrenia with loving realism". ScreenHub Australia. 30 April 2021. Retrieved 30 May 2022.

^ "I Met a Girl Review - Brenton Thwaites impresses with a proudly grounded and deeply empathetic performance". The Curb. 8 August 2021. Retrieved 30 May 2022.
